description: a(0) = 1, a(n) is the greatest prime factor of a(n-1)^2+1 for n > 0.
comments: Does this sequence grow indefinitely, or does it cycle? - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Oct 02 2006All a(n) except a(0) = 1 belong to A014442(n) = {2, 5, 5, 17, 13, 37, 5, 13, 41, 101, ...} Largest prime factor of n^2 + 1. All a(n) except a(0) = 1 belong to A002313(n) = {2, 5, 13, 17, 29, 37, 41, 53, 61, 73, 89, 97, 101, ...} Primes congruent to 1 or 2 modulo 4; or, primes of form x^2+y^2; or, -1 is a square mod p. All a(n) except a(0) = 1 and a(1) = 2 are the Pythagorean primes A002144(n) = {5, 13, 17, 29, 37, 41, 53, 61, 73, 89, 97, 101, ...} Primes of form 4n+1. - _Alexander Adamchuk_, Nov 05 2006Essentially the same as A072268; A72268(n) = A031439(n-1)^2 + 1. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, May 08 2009
links: Dennis Langdeau, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..24
Dario A. Alpern, Factorization: Elliptic Curve Method
mathematica: gpf[n_] := FactorInteger[n][[-1, 1]]; a[0] = 1; a[n_] := a[n] = gpf[a[n - 1]^2 + 1]; Table[an = a[n]; Print[an]; an, {n, 0, 21}] (* _Jean-Fran√ßois Alcover_, Nov 04 2011 *)NestList[FactorInteger[#^2+1][[-1,1]]&,1,21] (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Jul 04 2013 *)
crossrefs: Cf. A002144 - Pythagorean primes: primes of form 4n+1. Cf. A002313 - Primes congruent to 1 or 2 modulo 4. cf. A014442 - Largest prime factor of n^2 + 1.
author: _Yasutoshi Kohmoto_
extensions: One more term from _Vladeta Jovovic_, Nov 26 2001
